"**Yakety Yak** " is a song written, produced, and arranged by [Jerry Leiber
and Mike Stoller](/wiki/Jerry_Leiber_and_Mike_Stoller "Jerry Leiber and Mike
Stoller") for [The Coasters](/wiki/The_Coasters "The Coasters") and released
on [Atlantic Records](/wiki/Atlantic_Records "Atlantic Records") in
[1958](/wiki/1958_in_music "1958 in music"), spending seven weeks as #1 on
[the R&B charts](/wiki/List_of_number-
one_rhythm_and_blues_hits_\(United_States\) "List of number-one rhythm and
blues hits \(United States\)") and a week as [number
one](/wiki/Hot_100_number-one_hits_of_1958_\(USA\) "Hot 100 number-one hits of
1958 \(USA\)") on the [Top 100 pop list](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard
Hot 100").[1] This song was one of a string of singles released by The
Coasters between 1957 and 1959 that dominated the charts, one of the biggest
performing acts of the [rock and roll](/wiki/Rock_and_roll "Rock and roll")
era.[2]

## Song[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yakety_Yak&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Song")]

The song is a "playlet," a word Stoller used for the glimpses into teenage
life that characterized the songs Leiber and Stoller wrote and produced.[3]
The lyrics describe the listing of household chores to a kid, presumably a
teenager, the teenager's response ("yakety yak") and the parents' retort
("don't talk back") — an experience very familiar to a middle-class teenager
of the day. Leiber has said the Coasters portrayed "a white kid’s view of a
black person’s conception of white society."[2] The serio-comic street-smart
“playlets” etched out by the songwriters were sung by the Coasters with a sly
clowning humor, while the saxophone of [King Curtis](/wiki/King_Curtis "King
Curtis") filled in, in the up-tempo doo-wop style. The group was openly
"theatrical" in style—they were not pretending to be expressing their own
experience.[4]

The threatened punishment for not taking out the garbage and sweeping the
floor is, in the song's humorous lyrics:[5]

    "You ain't gonna rock and roll no more,"

And the refrain is:

    "Yakety yak; don't talk back."[6]

## Popular culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yakety_Yak&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Popular culture")]

  * Québécois duo [Les Jérolas](/wiki/Jean_Lapointe "Jean Lapointe") recorded in 1959 a French version "Rouspet' pas"
  * The sax solo by [King Curtis](/wiki/King_Curtis "King Curtis") inspired the 1963 [Boots Randolph](/wiki/Boots_Randolph "Boots Randolph") song "[Yakety Sax](/wiki/Yakety_Sax "Yakety Sax")"[7]
  * [Sha Na Na](/wiki/Sha_Na_Na "Sha Na Na") performed this as part of their set at the original [Woodstock Festival](/wiki/Woodstock_Festival "Woodstock Festival") and recorded 2 live covers of the song in 1971 and 1972
  * The song was covered by [Jan & Dean](/wiki/Jan_%26_Dean "Jan & Dean") and was planned to be released on their album _Carnival of Sound_ in 1968. _Carnival of Sound_ was not released until 2010.
  * [Lee Perry](/wiki/Lee_%22Scratch%22_Perry "Lee "Scratch" Perry") released a cover version in 1969 (as Lee Perry and the Upsetters), altering the lyric "You ain't gonna rock and roll no more" to "You ain't gonna reggae reggae reggae no more"
  * [The Pipkins](/wiki/The_Pipkins "The Pipkins") covered their song in 1970, produced by John Burgess.
  * Electronic/disco group El Coco covered this song in 1975 with some comedy elements, taken from their debut album, Mondo Disco, released on [AVI Records](/wiki/AVI_Records "AVI Records").
  * [Vince Vance & The Valiants](/wiki/Vince_Vance_%26_The_Valiants "Vince Vance & The Valiants"), one of multiple groups parodying [Barbara Ann](/wiki/Barbara_Ann "Barbara Ann") as "[Bomb Iran](/wiki/Bomb_Iran "Bomb Iran")" in 1980, created a similarly themed 2005 parody called "Yakety Yak (Bomb Iraq)".[8]
  * [Stand by Me](/wiki/Stand_by_Me_\(film\) "Stand by Me \(film\)"), the 1986 classic coming of age drama included "Yakety Yak" on its iconic soundtrack.
  * The song has also been mixed & recorded by [2 Live Crew](/wiki/2_Live_Crew "2 Live Crew") for the 1988 movie _[Twins](/wiki/Twins_\(1988_film\) "Twins \(1988 film\)")_. In the same film, Julius ([Arnold Schwarzenegger](/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger "Arnold Schwarzenegger")) sings along, with hilarious results, as the song plays in his earphones while flying to the United States.
  * The song is sung by the Coasters in the 1988 horror-comedy _Phantom of the Ritz_ which the four-man group makes a cameo appearance.
  * It has also served as the theme to [Clive Anderson](/wiki/Clive_Anderson "Clive Anderson")'s chat-show _Clive Anderson Talks Back_ during the 1990s, and as the opening theme of the 1988 movie _[The Great Outdoors](/wiki/The_Great_Outdoors_\(film\) "The Great Outdoors \(film\)")_.[9]
  * It was the inspiration and theme song for the 2002-2003 Canadian/Australian animated series, _[Yakkity Yak](/wiki/Yakkity_Yak "Yakkity Yak")_.[10]
  * A modified version, "Yakety Yak, Take it Back", was used in a 1990 all-star PSA for the Take It Back Foundation.[11]
  * A music video starring [Plucky Duck](/wiki/Plucky_Duck "Plucky Duck") as the kid tasked with chores, and a group of anthropomorphic yaks in police officer suits, aired on the 90th episode of _[Tiny Toon Adventures](/wiki/Tiny_Toon_Adventures "Tiny Toon Adventures")_ and used in _[The Plucky Duck Show](/wiki/The_Plucky_Duck_Show "The Plucky Duck Show")_.
  * The song was parodied for use in adverts for [Radox](/wiki/Radox "Radox") bath soak and [McCain](/wiki/McCain_Foods_Limited "McCain Foods Limited") Micro Chips in the 1980s and 1990s respectively.
  * The song name was used for the code name of [Ubuntu](/wiki/Ubuntu_\(operating_system\) "Ubuntu \(operating system\)") 16.10, a [Linux](/wiki/Linux "Linux") operating system with its [versions](/wiki/Ubuntu_version_history "Ubuntu version history") all named after animals.[12]
  * [Phantom Planet](/wiki/Phantom_Planet "Phantom Planet") covered this song for the soundtrack of the 1999 film _[Mumford](/wiki/Mumford_\(film\) "Mumford \(film\)")_.
